Abstract A new efficient hectonte-supported ruthenium catalyst showing molecular-sieve effects in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of alkylsubstituted benzenes to the corresponding cyclohexanes is described Key words Aromatic compounds, Hectonte, Hydrogenation, Ruthenium, Shape selectivity, Supported catalysts The hydrogenation of olefins and aromatic compounds with metallic ruthenium catalysts, supported on silica, zeolites and carbon, has been reported for gas-phase or liquid-phase reactions under low hydrogen pressure [ 1-3 ] . Only one example of hectonte-supported ruthenium, possessing shape-selective hydrogenation properties, is known so far, this catalyst was used for the gas-phase hydrogenation of olefins [ 4 ] Herein we report a new efficient hectonte-supported ruthenium catalyst showing molecular-sieve effects in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of alkylsubstituted benzenes to the corresponding cyclohexanes The new ruthenium catalyst is prepared by ion exchange of sodium-aqua hectonte (1) with [ (r~-C6H6)Ru(H2O)3] 2+, giving the ruthenium-complex modified hectonte 2 which is reduced to give the ruthenium-metal modified hectonte 3 (Scheme 1) The hectonte 1, presenting an idealized cell formula of Mg55Lio5S1802o(OH)4 Nato nH20, is synthesized according to the method of Bergk and Woldt [ 5 ] , the cation-exchange capacity is determined, according to the method of Lagaly [ 6 ] , to be 104 mequiv / 100 g The complex [ C6H6) Ru (H20) 3 ] 2 + is obtained by hydrolysis of [ (716-C6H6) RuC12 ] 2 [ 7 into a stainless-steel autoclave (working volume 100 cm 3), pressurized with 50 bar HZ and stirred at 100 C After 14 h the autoclave is cooled and the pressure released The hectonte catalyst 3 thus obtained is black, the swelling properties of the hectonte are retained because of the presence of remaining Na+(aq) ions (25%) In 3 The ruthenium loading of 3 is 3 2 wt%, the presence of mlcrocrystalllne metallic ruthenium between the hectonte layers is proven by its typical reflections in the X-ray diffraction pattern. For the determination of the particle size of the ruthenium crystallites inside the hectonte, transmission electron microscopy analysis was used [ 8 ] . The modified hectonte was therefore suspended in ethanol, sprayed on a carbon net-foil and then analyzed by the transmission electron microscope Philips CM 30 ST operating at o 300 kV Micrographs of 3 reveal a particle size of 90 to 180 A (Fig 1). On the right side of the micrograph the edges of superposed silicate layers are visible The lighter tone for the ruthenium particles on this side is typical for intercalated particles Surface and porosity studies for 3 were carried out using adsorption technics The sorption isotherm of N2 was measured with a Fisons Sorptomatic 1900 The specific surface of 3 was determined to be 207 m2/g, which is significantly higher than for the unmodified hectonte (87 m2/g) The maximum of occurrence for the pore size distribution of 3 is 19 8 A The catalytic activity of 3 is studied for the hydrogenation and the remaining pressure is released The hydrogenation products are identified by 'H O and GC, the yields and catalytic turnovers are determined by GC The observed catalytic turnover rate for the hydrogenation of benzene is comparable to the observed activity of unsupported ruthenium at 150-200 C [ 9 ] , but is achieved under considerably milder conditions (50 C) In order to assess the potential of 3 for the shape-selective hydrogenation of aromatic compounds, hydrogenation rates are measured for a number of linear and branched alkylsubstituted benzenes (Table 1) While hydrogenation proceeds readily for benzene, toluene and n-butylbenzene, significantly lower activity is observed for cumene and tent-butylbenzene This effect is due to the rising critical dimensions of these compounds Probably, tent-butylbenzene cannot enter the interlayer space of 3, but small quantities can be hydrogenated at ruthenium crystallites L126 A Meister et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysts 92 The ruthenium-metal hectonte 3 may be stored in air and shows a consistent rate of activity, even after 10 recycling operations.
